#Broadway

I have been experimenting a lot with GPT. I have had some exciting success at making chatbot characters like the Goat and Dixie Flatline from Neuromancer. These are fun, and they can do some fun LLM tricks, but they don't _actually do anything_.

I've been excited to keep up with @genmon@mastodon.social on his thoughts and work on LLMs. He recently posted about a hack project he undertook to build a LLM-powered home automation system.

https://interconnected.org/home/2023/04/26/lares

Cool! I was able to adapt one of the the technique he described - to provide the prompt with a "working memory" - and apply it to my own lighting automation system. Basically, I created a prompt that is like:

You can control the lights in my house. You can set the color, brightness, and turn them on and off. Here is a list of all the lights in the house:

<tab separated data from LIFX api>

To change a light, say:
SETLIGHT <id> <color> <brightness>

With these light weight instructions, the bot was immediately able to do things like turn on all the lights, turn off all the lights, turn on lights by name, turn on lights by room, set the lights to unplanned themes like "cyberpunk" or "relaxing" and answer questions about the state of the lights.

It did not ALWAYS work, but when it did, it was impressive enough. But what is REALLY interesting to me is not that it was able to change the lights (expected) but that it was able to dream up themes and coordinate settings across multiple rooms. That it had the features I planned, but also _adjacent features_ that I did not plan, let alone code.

You can give an LLM a set of data and some tools, and it can use them in unplanned ways. That is a really novel new aspect to the way we can build software.
